channel.title: GNOME question
channel.description: Does anyone know of any applications that allow you hit the meta key and search for applications like in GNOME 3 and Unity, except compatible with GNOME-Fallback mode?

item.title: GNOME question
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

AFAIK its a feature of Unity, although it could be a standalone program they include. Have you tried digging around in gconf-editor to see if you could find it?

Read full topic

item.title: GNOME question
item.dc:creator: @Daginith Daginith
item.description:
@Daginith wrote:

[quote=“ziplock, post:12, topic:439764”][quote author=Daginith link=topic=542456.msg3976288#msg3976288 date=1334695932]

Nono, I think most of you are misinterpreting my objective.

Can you rephrase it, lol, i dont know exactly what you mean?

Like an interpreted pregram within the terminal that allows you to put input to open a program…i.e.:
you type in ‘Terminal’ and it opens ‘Xterm’?
[/quote]

If you have ever used GNOME3 or Unity, when you hit the meta key it opens a search bar that searches for applications and files in real time, as you type them. That’s what I want.[/quote]
Oh yeah.

I remember using this on my old Linux Distro a while back.
http://projects.gnome.org/deskbar-applet/

It opens up a GUI, whick you can easily bind to a key.
Im not 100% sure thats exactly what you wanted, but just check it out

Read full topic

item.title: GNOME question
item.dc:creator: @ziplock ziplock
item.description:
@ziplock wrote:

[quote=“Daginith, post:11, topic:439764”][quote author=ziplock link=topic=542456.msg3976285#msg3976285 date=1334695813]
Nono, I think most of you are misinterpreting my objective.
[/quote]
Can you rephrase it, lol, i dont know exactly what you mean?

Like an interpreted pregram within the terminal that allows you to put input to open a program…i.e.:
you type in ‘Terminal’ and it opens ‘Xterm’?[/quote]

If you have ever used GNOME3 or Unity, when you hit the meta key it opens a search bar that searches for applications and files in real time, as you type them. That’s what I want.

Read full topic

item.title: GNOME question
item.dc:creator: @Daginith Daginith
item.description:
@Daginith wrote:

Wouldn’t it be easier to just set key bindings? I know that the down side is that you might forget them…Or just use Conky, and make a list of them on the side, haha.

nixCraft – 30 Jul 07

Create / modify keyboard shortcuts in Gnome under Linux / UNIX - nixCraft

Q. Iâ€™m using Ubuntu Linux and Iâ€™d like to create or modify keyboard shortcuts in Gnome desktop system? How do I do it? A. You need to use GConf-Editor or gnome keyboard shortcut tool. GConf-Editor is a tool used for editing the GConf...

Read full topic

item.title: GNOME question
item.dc:creator: @ziplock ziplock
item.description:
@ziplock wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:7, topic:439764”][quote author=ziplock link=topic=542456.msg3975778#msg3975778 date=1334630858]
Yes, I’m just looking for a program that will have a close functionality to when you hit the meta key in GNOME3, an example is, when I hit the meta key I want a little real-time search bar that searches for applications or files as I type there names in. So I can easily just hit the META and type “terminal” and I am looking at a terminal. I realize that there is a “run” dialog box but it requires I type the exact name of the application, and it is not as fast.
[/quote]
oh, so a mac finder?[/quote]

Ha, yeah pretty much.

Read full topic

item.title: GNOME question
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

ziplock:

Yes, I’m just looking for a program that will have a close functionality to when you hit the meta key in GNOME3, an example is, when I hit the meta key I want a little real-time search bar that searches for applications or files as I type there names in. So I can easily just hit the META and type “terminal” and I am looking at a terminal. I realize that there is a “run” dialog box but it requires I type the exact name of the application, and it is not as fast.

oh, so a mac finder?

Read full topic

item.title: GNOME question
item.dc:creator: @Daginith Daginith
item.description:
@Daginith wrote:

You can run OpenBox within Gnome as the WM, and set key bindings.

All you have to do is use GNOME as the DM, and OpenBox as the WM.

Read full topic

item.title: GNOME question
item.dc:creator: @ziplock ziplock
item.description:
@ziplock wrote:

Yes, I’m just looking for a program that will have a close functionality to when you hit the meta key in GNOME3, an example is, when I hit the meta key I want a little real-time search bar that searches for applications or files as I type there names in. So I can easily just hit the META and type “terminal” and I am looking at a terminal. I realize that there is a “run” dialog box but it requires I type the exact name of the application, and it is not as fast.

It is not a utility that is shipped with it, and I’m not sure of any third party ones.

item.title: GNOME question
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

in XFCE, there’s a way to set global key-bindings easily, i’d assume GNOME has the same options. is this an existing utility? if so you can just bind to that application (launch it when you press meta). else, you could make your own.

Read full topic
